author: Kelly Terez
title: Cameron Heyward Fighting Fine for Eye Black Honoring Late Father
text:
Share Article 
Jared Wickerham/Getty Images (PITTSBURGH, Pa.) -- Pittsburgh Steelers defensive end Cameron Heyward is fighting to honor his late father on the field. 
On Tuesday, Heyward has an appeal scheduled after he was fined $5,787 for writing "Iron Head" on his eye black as a tribute to his father, Craig “Ironhead” Heyward, who died from a brain tumor. 
The National Football League is allowing players to pay tribute to breast cancer awareness month this October, by wearing pink shoes and wristbands, but Heyward thinks players should be allowed to pay tribute to other cancers. 
“A lot of people are struggling with cancer and that’s what my message was,” Heyward said Monday according to the Pittsburgh Post-Gazette . “It’s not just about me and my love for my father. There are a lot of people out there struggling. In a month when breast cancer is honored I think every type of cancer should be honored as well.” 
According to the Post-Gazette , Heyward said he would continue to wear the eye black for the rest of the month, even though the fine for the next offense would escalate to $11,576.
